trans-unit.source: Converts data input to the internal Dataset format used by Microsoft Azure Machine Learning
trans-unit.target: Converts data input to the internal Dataset format used by Microsoft Azure Machine Learning

trans-unit.source: You can use the <ui>Convert to Dataset</ui> module to convert any data that you might need for an experiment to the internal format used by Studio.
trans-unit.target: You can use the <ui>Convert to Dataset</ui> module to convert any data that you might need for an experiment to the internal format used by Studio.

trans-unit.source: Conversion is not strictly required, because Azure Machine Learning implicitly converts data to its native dataset format when any operation is performed on the data.
trans-unit.target: Conversion is not strictly required, because Azure Machine Learning implicitly converts data to its native dataset format when any operation is performed on the data.

trans-unit.source: However, saving data to the dataset format is recommended if you have performed some kind of normalization or cleaning on a set of data, and you want to ensure that the changes are used in further experiments.
trans-unit.target: However, saving data to the dataset format is recommended if you have performed some kind of normalization or cleaning on a set of data, and you want to ensure that the changes are used in further experiments.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Convert to Dataset</ui> changes only the format of the data, and it does not save a new copy of the data in the workspace.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Convert to Dataset</ui> changes only the format of the data, and it does not save a new copy of the data in the workspace.

trans-unit.source: To save the dataset, double-click the output port and select <ui>Save as dataset</ui>.
trans-unit.target: To save the dataset, double-click the output port and select <ui>Save as dataset</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Depending on the input to this module, the following options are provided:
trans-unit.target: Depending on the input to this module, the following options are provided:

trans-unit.source: The dataset is converted in its current format, with no special handling of sparse columns or missing values.
trans-unit.target: The dataset is converted in its current format, with no special handling of sparse columns or missing values.

trans-unit.source: You can use this option to specify a placeholder that will be inserted in the dataset wherever there is a missing value.
trans-unit.target: You can use this option to specify a placeholder that will be inserted in the dataset wherever there is a missing value.

trans-unit.source: The default placeholder is the question mark character (?).
trans-unit.target: The default placeholder is the question mark character (?).

trans-unit.source: Type the new value to use when replacing missing values.
trans-unit.target: Type the new value to use when replacing missing values.

trans-unit.source: You can use this option to specify a custom value replacement, which you can apply to any single value.
trans-unit.target: You can use this option to specify a custom value replacement, which you can apply to any single value.

trans-unit.source: For example, you might look for missing values represented by a question mark (?) and replace them with another character.
trans-unit.target: For example, you might look for missing values represented by a question mark (?) and replace them with another character.

trans-unit.source: This option lets you specify a method for handling missing values when creating a sparse data vector, so that missing values do not affect a sparse data distribution.
trans-unit.target: This option lets you specify a method for handling missing values when creating a sparse data vector, so that missing values do not affect a sparse data distribution.

trans-unit.source: If the option <ui>Remove zeroes</ui> is set to <languageKeyword>True</languageKeyword>, all zero entities are removed when the sparse column is created.
trans-unit.target: If the option <ui>Remove zeroes</ui> is set to <languageKeyword>True</languageKeyword>, all zero entities are removed when the sparse column is created.

trans-unit.source: You can see examples of how this module is used by exploring these sample experiments in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>:
trans-unit.target: You can see examples of how this module is used by exploring these sample experiments in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>:

trans-unit.source: The <externalLink><linkText>CRM sample</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525941</linkUri></externalLink> reads from a shared dataset and saves a copy of the dataset in the local workspace.
trans-unit.target: The <externalLink><linkText>CRM sample</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525941</linkUri></externalLink> reads from a shared dataset and saves a copy of the dataset in the local workspace.

trans-unit.source: The <externalLink><linkText>Flight Delay example</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525725</linkUri></externalLink> saves a dataset that has been cleaned by replacing missing values so that you can use it for future experiments.
trans-unit.target: The <externalLink><linkText>Flight Delay example</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525725</linkUri></externalLink> saves a dataset that has been cleaned by replacing missing values so that you can use it for future experiments.

trans-unit.source: Any module that takes a dataset as input can also take data in the CSV, TSV, or ARFF formats.
trans-unit.target: Any module that takes a dataset as input can also take data in the CSV, TSV, or ARFF formats.

trans-unit.source: Before any module code is executed, preprocessing of the inputs is performed, which is equivalent to running the <ui>Convert to Dataset</ui> module on the input.
trans-unit.target: Before any module code is executed, preprocessing of the inputs is performed, which is equivalent to running the <ui>Convert to Dataset</ui> module on the input.

trans-unit.source: If the dataset you are converting does not have column names, use the <link xlink:href="370b6676-c11c-486f-bf73-35349f842a66" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Metadata Editor</link> to prepare the dataset before using <ui>Convert to Dataset</ui>.
trans-unit.target: If the dataset you are converting does not have column names, use the <link xlink:href="370b6676-c11c-486f-bf73-35349f842a66" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Metadata Editor</link> to prepare the dataset before using <ui>Convert to Dataset</ui>.

trans-unit.source: You cannot convert from the SVMLight format to dataset.
trans-unit.target: You cannot convert from the SVMLight format to dataset.

trans-unit.source: When specifying a custom replace operation, the search and replace operation applies to complete values; partial matches are not allowed.
trans-unit.target: When specifying a custom replace operation, the search and replace operation applies to complete values; partial matches are not allowed.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can replace a 3 with a -1 or with 33, but you cannot replace a 3 in a two-digit number such as 35.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can replace a 3 with a -1 or with 33, but you cannot replace a 3 in a two-digit number such as 35.

trans-unit.source: For custom replace operations, the replacement will silently fail if you use as a replacement any character that does not conform to the current data type of the column.
trans-unit.target: For custom replace operations, the replacement will silently fail if you use as a replacement any character that does not conform to the current data type of the column.

trans-unit.source: If you need to save data that uses numerical data that is sparse and has missing values, internally, Studio supports sparse arrays by using a SparseVector, which is a class in the Math.NET numeric library.
trans-unit.target: If you need to save data that uses numerical data that is sparse and has missing values, internally, Studio supports sparse arrays by using a SparseVector, which is a class in the Math.NET numeric library.

trans-unit.source: Prepare your data that uses zeros and has missing values, and then use <ui>Convert to Dataset</ui> with the arguments <ui>SparseOutput</ui> and <ui>Remove Zeros = yes</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Prepare your data that uses zeros and has missing values, and then use <ui>Convert to Dataset</ui> with the arguments <ui>SparseOutput</ui> and <ui>Remove Zeros = yes</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Action to apply to input dataset
trans-unit.target: Action to apply to input dataset
